context.text: At the present time information systems including a variety of various embedded and mobile devices are becoming increasingly important [5].

The key features of IoT systems are as follows [5]: 1) resource constraints imposed on both the device capabilities and the ability to protect them; 2) larger subjection of such devices to malicious actions of an intruder on the physical level.
The structure and its functions as well as the security subsystem of an IoT system depend highly on a particular application domain under consideration [2], [5].

The most important design challenges and major concerns in the field of IoT systems include the following problems: dissipation of power and other kind of resources [4], [5]; security of data located in a device under assumption it can be lost or stolen [5]; exposure to side-channel attacks [4]; reduced performance of IoT devices [4]; user identification; arrangement of highly secure communications between devices [7] and others.
Following [5] we note the development of IoT systems cannot be reduced solely to the models and methods traditionally used in Electrical Engineering.
In fact in accordance with [5] individual devices of IoT systems (i.e. embedded devices) are defined as ones, which computing process is closely related to reaction to the physical environment.

For embedded devices, which are characterized by computation within specific physical constraints, Henzinger and Sifakis justify an importance of making trade-offs between security and non-functional characteristics of devices such as performance, applying optimization approaches [5] and combining end devices from individual components according to their properties and requirements [5].

context.text: In many real control problems, such as a rapid thermal processing [9], the only available measurement is the terminal state or terminal output, and the ultimate control objective is also the terminal state or terminal output, instead of the whole trajectory of the system.
To overcome these problems, terminal ILC (TILC) [9]–[16] is introduced to handle the terminal output tracking problem using the terminal point at the end of every run.
It was first proposed for rapid thermal processing chemical vapor deposition [9], [10] to control the deposition thickness at the end of the thermal processing cycle.
In general, the design and analysis of existing TILC [9]–[16] is mainly limited to a linear system framework although the experiments are for nonlinear systems.
However, two major issues still remain in the work of [17] and other existing TILCs [9]–[16].

Although the time-varying control input signals are utilized and updated in [9]–[11], it is required to parameterize the control function using a predetermined time-varying continuous functional basis and then to update the coefficients based on the terminal output error measurement at the end of each system repetition.

The second problem of existing TILCs [9]–[17] is that it is generally unable to add any feedback information of the previous time instants in the current run to enhance control performance because the system output measurements are impossible at all the intermediate points except for the terminal endpoint.
Although the control input is time-varying, the design of the learning control law does not depend on a basis function as in [9]–[11].

Moretti, for example, makes extensive use of static graphs and network visualizations [27], Plaisant et al. use an interactive visualization, which features scatterplots to analyze Emily Dickinson [31], and word clouds are frequently used to investigate emergent themes in large and small-scale document corpora (see Jockers [25, chpt. 8]).

This space differs from related application contexts that have previously been discussed in the visualization research community, such as casual or artistic scenarios [33], libraries [46], museums [3], [21], or journalism [5] by drawing from and expanding recent digital humanities discussions that seek to address critically the potential of information visualization in their research [13], [16], [17], [25], [27].

Computational methods, including information visualization, have the potential to facilitate the study of larger document collections, literature, photographs, or other cultural artefacts from a humanities perspective [25], [27], [42].

The humanities repertoire of traditional research methods, many of which depend on close reading or the careful study, analysis, and interpretation of a small number of selected individual texts [25], is expanding to include what Moretti has named distant reading [27], [28]—macro-level approaches to large-scale literary collections, using quantitatively-based methods of analysis.

Quantitative approaches to literature have not remained without critique, as they seem to suggest a fundamental shift from traditional constructivist practices that are based on fine-grained, qualitative observation and critical interpretation [13], [25], toward positivist approaches where the complexity and ambiguity of literary forms is reduced, even impoverished, in favour of abstraction and quantification [13], [26].
Similarly, Jockers proposes a hybrid approach, which he calls macroanalysis [25].

Trust calibration is influenced by all the dimensions mentioned by Muir [58]: The “expectation of the persistence of natural physical laws” allows for the creation and usage of mental models (or rule bases).

Finally, fiduciary responsibility “is invoked as a basis for trust when the trustor's own technical competence is exceeded by the referent's [(in our case the VA-system)], or is not known to him” [58].

The claim by Muir that “the trust in a machine, once betrayed, may be hard to recover” [58] is backed up by Manzey's study that revealed a similar relationship between error and subjective trust [56].
Furthermore, knowledge includes many sub-components that influence trust building (e.g., the technical competence or subjective attitudes [58]).
This trust depends on the humans technical competence and familiarity with the system and its subcomponents (as described by Muir [58]).

Recently, a new and generalized statistical model, Málaga (\$\mathcal{M}\$) distribution, was proposed in [17] to model the irradiance fluctuation of an unbounded optical wavefront (plane or spherical waves) propagating through a turbulent medium under all irradiance conditions in homogeneous, isotropic turbulence [18].

This \$\mathcal{M}\$ distribution unifies most of the proposed statistical models derived until now in the bibliography in a closed-form expression providing an excellent agreement with published simulation data over a wide range of turbulence conditions (weak to strong) [17].

The \$\mathcal{M}\$ turbulence model [17] is based on a physical model that involves a line-of-sight (LOS) contribution, \$U_{L}\$, a component that is quasi-forward scattered by the eddies on the propagation axis and coupled to the LOS contribution, \$U_{S}^{C}\$, and another component, \$U_{S}^{G}\$, due to energy that is scattered to the receiver by off-axis eddies. \$U_{S}^{C}\$ and \$U_{S}^{G}\$ are statistically independent random processes and \$U_{L}\$ and \$U_{S}^{G}\$ are also independent random processes.
The \$\mathcal{M}\$ turbulence model can be visually understood via [17].

context.text: In order to both provide more network capacity and reduce the network power consumption, the concept of massive MIMO has been introduced in the research community [2].

The alternative approach, requesting each user terminal to measure the channel in downlink and send the corresponding measurements, would consume excessive resources for training and suffer from outdated channels in a mobile context [2].

Conceptually, massive MIMO systems are based on the following key elements [2]:


•
A large number of base station antennas, much larger than the number of served users,


•
A time-domain duplexing frame structure, where uplink pilots are used in order to let the base station estimate the channel,


•
A MU-MIMO precoding approach, building on the channel state information; similarly in uplink a detection based on the same precoder,


•
Low-cost, low-power and low-accuracy individual antenna chains.

Intermediate integration techniques are very similar to the early integration ones

The main difficulty with intermediate integration is the limitation in selecting the modeling techniques because they should be designed specifically for the intermediate integration process 
[57].

The most straightforward techniques used in this step are weighting, summation, and voting
